sec.p: Canberra Secondary was among the 13 new secondary schools which opened on 3 January 2000 with Mr Puvan Ariaratnam as the pioneer principal. The school was housed in Sembawang Secondary School's premises at Sembawang Crescent before it moved to its own school at 51 Sembawang Road in June 2000. The astute principal, Mr. Puvan Ariaratnam, has guided the school towards carving a niche of excellence in Information Technology (IT) and multimedia which is pervasive in the school's distinctive educational strategies and infrastructure. Before his appointment to the school, he taught in a junior college, was the Vice-Principal of a secondary school and also served stints in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Education. He has been instrumental in the rise of Canberra’s prominence in its initial years of administration. He was succeeded by Mr Tan Keng Joo in 2006 who is currently the prime mover for the school's excellence.

The school gain popularity in various programs but notably in Video Production. The school had a CCA club call The Arts and Innovation Club or AI for short. It was run by Mr. Adrian Lim who trained, supervised and nurtured a group of dedicated students to conceive, produce and execute video projects. They participated in the Schools Video Awards from 2000 to 2005 winning a record of 4 Gold, 1 platinum and 1 Silver award. They also swept awards at the Panasonic KWN competition and represented Singapore in the world competition on august 2005 coming in third place with the best award for news presentation, a feat that has yet to be surpassed.

sec.p: Own Your Learning Programme (OYL) is carried out to acquire students with a motivational, good studying practice towards a results-oriented goal. Personal reflections are carried out weekly to monitor their own progress with the guidance of their home-tutors in ensuring every day of the week has been effectively utilized. In addition, students are facilitated with useful advice on their multi-disciplinary and inter-personal conduct towards school-life balance.

Excellence Programme is a preparatory after-school program for the Singapore Cambridge (UCLES) N/O-Levels, catering to upper secondary students with the agenda of covering the topics in the syllabus at an accelerated pace and developing their content knowledge and relevant skills. The program is integral in the curriculum. The degree of flexibility of the program lies in the choice and teaching style of the teachers whereby various needs of most students has to be fulfilled. This was inaugurated in the academic year of 2007. The 'O' level results proved the effectiveness of this system with the proliferation of more students with better scores and eligibility for admission into Junior College.

Apart from the Co-curricular Activities, the students, especially student leaders, are actively involved in activities leadership camps and internal school activities organized by the student councilors. Sports and Arts Festival are held yearly at the CCAB where sports tournament are held annually. These efforts constantly seek to foster a vibrant environment and enthusiastic spirit within the students. Successes of these activities are indicated in the proliferation of student participation. In the long run, the extrinsic nature of the activities has became an intrinsic part in the student population - worthy of mention would be the popular Ultimate Frisbee culture in the school.

This programme is inaugurated by the Craft and Technology (C&T) department working on a joint service project with the Handicaps Welfare Association (HWA) which involved upper secondary Home Economics (HE), Art (AR) Design and Technology (T) pupils. The initials of these three subjects, when joined together, form the word, “HEART”, thus the project name, “Winning Hearts” whereby we inspire to win hearts, as a team.

It serves to infuse students’ project assignments into an Integrated Project Work (IPW) for the department. It also provides opportunities for pupils to undergo experiential learning and provides real-life situations for them to work on in their coursework. Pupils can also help to improve the quality of the lives of the handicapped. As such, this collaboration can be deemed as a community involvement project whereby the students undergo holistic service learning.
Global Canberrans Programme

The school believes in providing a holistic education for pupils and this is evident in our holistic character development that builds our pupils’ character. In line with the school’s vision of “A Global Institution of Learning”, the pupils are given every opportunity to engage in learning with the community as well as collaboration with local and international institutions. This is to enable students to be creative and innovative thinkers, ready to face the challenges and demands of the 21st century. As part of the school's academic and character development, Global Canberrans Programme was initiated for pupils to facilitate this internationalisation process.
